Posts.Content: Originally Posted by daughtertakescharge1987 Hi, I'm new to this forum (and forums in general) so forgive me if I'm doing this wrong -- my 65 year old father was just diagnosed with stage 4 metastatic prostate cancer, it has spread to lymphs and the bones in his left shoulder and forearm. He is pretty much computer illiterate so I have decided to take the reigns and do the research for him. His PSA levels were 1053.6 ng/mL which seems INSANELY high, and the doctors have him on Lupron depot every 6 months and have him scheduled to start chemo in August. He is also very poor and is on every government program for assistance that he has been able to qualify for. We are trying to be as hopeful and optimistic as possible, and not enough time has passed since starting treatment to see if it is having any effect, but I would like to know if anyone has been in a similar situation, or has any comments at all based on what little information I have provided. Im trying to stay positive and learn as much as I can but his situation is seeming pretty bleak. When I asked for the prognosis his oncologist mumbled something like "it could be months or years" and I really have no idea what that means. I know every patient is different but are we actually looking at a possibility of death in a few months? Any suggestions or advice or opinions or ANYTHING would be so so appreciated. Thank you all! Welcome to the site. Sorry to hear the news about your father. . You have certainly come to the right place to get information and to gain knowledge. There are many threads on this site from very knowledgeable people. I am certainly no expert on prostate cancer so I will leave it to those who know way more than I do. But I will point out that if you use the search function up in the right hand corner of this page, you will be able to find information that is helpful to you and your father. May I suggest searching for stage 4 or metastatic cancer or both. The search will narrow down the threads to a more manageable level. You will find threads from men that have survived for many years with stage 4 cancer. As you stated, everyone is different, so these stories may not be your father's outcome but you will gain important knowledge. Good luck with this journey. There is progress toward finding a cure for this disease. It seems to be a difficult one to solve but them seem to be getting closer every day. The other day I read an article in the Chicago Tribune how researchers at Northwestern Hospital in Chicago have found a way to stop cancer from metastasizing. This is just another step in figuring out how cancer works and may lead to ways to cure it. Good luck and God Bless. Ed
Posts.Title: recently diagnosed, stage 4 spread to bones and lymphs, psa of 1053.6...

Posts.Content: thanks caddy 2507. I am not opposed to have a little whiskey. Actually I enjoy trying some of the new bourbons that are in the market! I have worked with a physical therapist a few times. She has told me to drink as much water as I do the alcoholic drink. It will reduce the irritation of the bladder. It told her that my bladder was very familiar with beer before my surgery and it never seemed to be an irritant. She said the bladder has now become used to water so have to retrain it. I have had the same amount of water that I have had in beer and it seems to work. I will keep testing her theory because there are a lot of craft beer I have not tried. Thanks for responding to my post.
Posts.Title: Incontinence - is my situation odd?

Posts.Content: I am six months from my DaVinci radical prostatectomy. My situation seems to be the opposite of a lot of men on this site. Most men are dry during the night first and then dry during the day. I am dry during the day but leak at night. If I sleep more than 3 hours, I seem to leak pretty well. I have had a beer at night with my dinner (needed something besides water, water, water). Have had some water after dinner small amounts up until bedtime and have tried not having anything to drink for 3 hours before bed. Still seem to leak although not drinking anything for three hours did work in occasion. Has anyone else had a situation similar to mine? If so, was it ever resolved? Will I be able to have something to drink after dinner ever again without leaking? Prior to the surgery, I could drink anything I wanted at night and still sleep through the night. Any help will be greatly appreciated. Ed
Posts.Title: Incontinence - is my situation odd?

Posts.Content: Thanks RobLee. Sorry to hear abut your situation. I will have to try the washcloth. I currently am sleeping in my jockey underwear with a pair of shorts over the top. Some night s the jockey's are just a little damp while other nights the leakage goes through the outer pair of shorts. I was hoping the new normal would be completely dry for both the day and night. I haven't given up hope yet...
Posts.Title: Incontinence - is my situation odd?

Posts.Content: Thanks lastchance for responding. Glad your recovery went well for you and you were dry quickly.

Posts.Content: I found the comment earlier by Michael F that 61 grams was about twice the normal size of a prostate. I just received a copy of my pathology report and my prostate was 55.8 grams. According to the earlier post, my prostate was getting pretty close to double the normal size. Yet my GP said he did not think anything was wrong with my prostate after a DRE while the uro said it felt slightly enlarged! Am I missing something here? Or is it that Doctors should not rely that much on the DRE since they are only touching about 25% of the prostate? Just an FYI, the biopsy should a Gleason of 3+3 and 3+4 with 10 of 12 cores positive for cancer. After surgery, the pathology came back with 4+3 with positive margin at the apex. Any thoughts gentlemen? Ed

Posts.Title: Prostate size and volume calculations

Posts.Content: Merry Christmas Everyone!!! I am 14 months post DaVinci Radical Prostatectomy. I am still experiencing some leakage at night and stress incontinence when walking for exercise or performing tasks around the house. One of the items the surgeon has suggested is to have a mesh installed to deal with the stress incontinence. Just wondering if anyone has had this procedure or has any other solutions to this problem. Have tried to do research online to determine the success rate of this surgery but am having trouble finds stats for men. Noticed that there a lot of attorneys advertising because of botched mesh surgeries on women so a little nervous about proceeding with this surgery without getting some better information. Hope everyone is doing well and enjoying the Holidays with your friends and family. Your input, as always, is greatly appreciated! Ed
Posts.Signature: Age 65 Biopsy 7/27/17 9 of 12 cores with cancer Gleason scores of 3+3 in 8 cores, 3+4 in 1 core. Cancer as % of cores range 20-70. Prolaris Genetic Test 8/11/17 10 year mortality 2.5% Low risk of metastasis (based DaVinci Surgery 10/9/17 Dr. Berger Advocate Christ Hospital Pathology Gleason upgraded to 4+3, Bilateral lobes involved 40% of prostate Left apex involved Perineural invasion Apical, base, semi bilateral vesicle margins and circumferential resection margins negative Left Lymph nodes negative for metastatic carcinoma PSA History 2007 1.92 2008 2.40 2009 3.06 2010 2.46 2011 3.40 2012 4.10 2013 4.40 2014 4.00 2015 4.70 2017 5.7 2017 5.3 Drs. believed nothing was wrong and were SHOCKED at biopsy results. 2/18 <.01 undetectable; 5/18<.01 undetectable;10/18 <.01 undetectable
Posts.Title: Has anyone had mesh installed for stress incontinence?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I know nothing about the mesh question. A question I have for the doctor is does it impact future radiation if radiation is necessary for BCR. Are your PSA numbers <0.01 or <0.1? Did you try giving up alcohol, caffeine, and carbonated beverages for a while to see if it makes a difference? How's your weight? Is your BMI between 19 and 24? Are you doing your kegels correctly? Have you tried physical therapy wirth a specialist in pelvic floor muscles? In other words, try everything before choosing surgery solutions, imo. I gave up alcohol, caffeine and carbonated beverages for close to a year. Since it didn't seem to improve the situation, I have one cup of coffee in the morning and maybe a beer with my dinner on occasion. Gained about 10 pounds after surgery because of a lack of activity but my BMI is around the 24 number. I worked with a Physical Therapist who identified that kegels was part of the problem because I experienced pain when doing them. She recommended doing reverse kegels which seemed to help with the leakage but still have the stress and leakage at night.

Posts.Content: Yes, sorry, I meant sling procedure. Thanks for the information on the sling procedure. I had my doubts that it would get me to where I want to be. I can certainly live like this but really was hoping to get back to a dry state and close to the quality of life I had. Doesn't seem like it is going to happen. I sleep in my BVDs and they are a little dam in the morning. Usually wake up and void after about 5 hours of sleep and then return to bed to see if I can get a couple of hours more. After 3 blood tests, PSA is <.01 so that situation is very good.

Posts.Content: Bravehardon Can you share some of the exercises you were doing? How about how many Kegels did you do a day? My doctor has me doing 300, 200 quick and 100 hold for 10 seconds. I am wondering because Mayo Clinic has their patients do 7 a day which quite a bit less than 300. SOrt of taking my own little survey. Ed
Posts.Title: Need Physical Therapist Recommendation Daytona Beach area

Posts.Content: Happy and Healthy New Year to All! I am a snowbird from the Chicago area, currently residing in the Daytona Beach Florida area. I had me Da Vinci radical prostatectomy on October 9, 2017. I received a prescription from my surgeon, Dr Aaron Berger, for some physical therapy for my incontinence. Since I will be staying in this area most of the winter, I am looking for recommendations for a good physical therapist that has a specialty in handling male incontinence. Dont mind driving an hour or so to find the right PT, meaning Orlando, Jacksonville or Titusville. Any recommendations will be greatly appreciated. Thanks, Ed
Posts.Title: Need Physical Therapist Recommendation Daytona Beach area

Posts.Content: Bracehardon Thanks for the encouraging words. I hope I can find a person with a PHD and only works with men after surgery. Unfortunately, in my searching for a PT, I have not found one that only works with men. Most of the PTs I have found, work primarily with women. I will certainly take Consult1's advice regarding the pelvic floor certification. Happy New Year! Thanks, Ed
Posts.Title: Need Physical Therapist Recommendation Daytona Beach area

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 I don't have a specific therapist to recommend, but when you're doing your search you might check to see if any potential therapist has completed the specialty pelvic floor certification course by APTA (American Physical Therapy Association). Thanks. That is very good advice. Happy New Year! Ed
Posts.Title: Need Physical Therapist Recommendation Daytona Beach area

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon Hi Ed, my exercise program is as follows. Firstly using ultra sensitive food scale I had to keep track of urine weight at the end of each day: * Three times a day perform kegel exercise as follows: 1) lift floor 25% and hold 5 seconds, lift floor to maximum and hold 10 seconds, lift floor 25% and hold 5 seconds., take a 60 second break and repeat a total of 10 times. Do exercise 3 times day (morning, afternoon,night). * Lift floor to maximum, drop quickly to base 20 times (repeat as above). * once per day walk for 30 minutes while raising bottom floor to 25% and holding for entire walk. The above worked well for me. Good luck Allen Thanks for the info. Kegels are much more involved than what I am currently doing. Will have to give it a try. Thanks, Ed
Posts.Title: Need Physical Therapist Recommendation Daytona Beach area
